articles.headline: Soaring Ointment Prices Are a Dermatologic Mystery
articles.snippet: Generic creams routinely prescribed by doctors have been undergoing rapid price increases, an example of the murky and often illogical world of drug pricing.
articles.abstract: Generic creams routinely prescribed by doctors have been undergoing rapid price increases, an example of the murky and often illogical world of drug pricing.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are the staples of most dermatology practices: generic creams and ointments that treat everything from skin rashes to athlete’s foot to scabies. Many doctors prescribe the drugs without a second thought. But increasingly, some dermatologists say, patients are complaining about a recent, mysterious and rapid rise in price.

articles.headline: Best Buy Suffers for Lack of a Plan
articles.snippet: Best Buy, struggling to deal with competition from Amazon.com and turmoil in its leadership, might have avoided some of its problems by planning for the departure of its chief executive.
articles.abstract: Best Buy, struggling to deal with competition from Amazon.com and turmoil in its leadership, might have avoided some of its problems by planning for the departure of its chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confronted with an extraordinary situation, the board of Best Buy, the large electronics retailer, did what good corporate governance practices required. It fired the chief executive.

articles.headline: Former Goldman Programmer Is Arrested Again
articles.snippet: The Manhattan district attorney has charged Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer, with state crimes related to his downloading of computer code from his onetime employer.
articles.abstract: The Manhattan district attorney has charged Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer, with state crimes related to his downloading of computer code from his onetime employer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The legal odyssey of a former Goldman Sachs programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, took a surprising turn on Thursday when the Manhattan district attorney charged him with state crimes.

articles.headline: Manchester United Prices I.P.O. at $14 a Share
articles.snippet: Manchester United on Thursday priced its initial public offering at $14 a share, valuing the 134-year-old English soccer team at about $2.3 billion. The price is below the range of $16 to $20 it outlined last week.
articles.abstract: Manchester United on Thursday priced its initial public offering at $14 a share, valuing the 134-year-old English soccer team at about $2.3 billion. The price is below the range of $16 to $20 it outlined last week.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Real Estate Deal, Romney Made His Loss a Couple’s Gain
articles.snippet: Sandwiched among the hedge funds in Mitt Romney’s portfolio is less than $2,500 in annual interest income from the mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stamps’s Texas home.
articles.abstract: Sandwiched among the hedge funds in Mitt Romney’s portfolio is less than $2,500 in annual interest income from the mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stamps’s Texas home.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSOURI CITY, Tex. — Look closely and it is there, sandwiched between Goldman Sachs Hedge Fund Partners II and D3 Family Bulldog Fund: the mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stamps’s modest home on Gentle Bend Drive here.

articles.headline: Male Couples Face Pressure to Fill Cradles
articles.snippet: As acceptance of same-sex marriage and parenthood grows, many gay couples find themselves answering the double-edged questions.
articles.abstract: As acceptance of same-sex marriage and parenthood grows, many gay couples find themselves answering the double-edged questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the jubilant couple were wed in June, they exchanged personalized vows and titanium rings, cheered the heartfelt toasts and danced themselves breathless. Then, as the evening was winding down, unexpected questions started popping up.

articles.headline: The Campaign to Digitize Your Wallet Is Intensifying
articles.snippet: There is no shortage of companies trying to dominate the nascent mobile payment industry, but consumers have yet to be won over.
articles.abstract: There is no shortage of companies trying to dominate the nascent mobile payment industry, but consumers have yet to be won over.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, Starbucks joined forces with Square, a technology start-up that lets you pay for things with a smartphone. Coming from a company whose cafes seem to be on every corner, that’s a powerful endorsement. Does that mean your phone will soon replace your wallet?

articles.headline: Regulator Shines a Spotlight on a Bank, and on Himself
articles.snippet: Aggressive action by Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, against the British bank Standard Chartered has some wondering about his tactics and his ultimate goals.
articles.abstract: Aggressive action by Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, against the British bank Standard Chartered has some wondering about his tactics and his ultimate goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the evening before Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, issued highly charged money laundering claims against a British bank, he spoke with the Manhattan district attorney.

articles.headline: Shopper Alert: Price May Drop for You Alone
articles.snippet: Supermarkets are mining the data from their loyalty card programs to adjust prices for and make marketing offers to individual customers.
articles.abstract: Supermarkets are mining the data from their loyalty card programs to adjust prices for and make marketing offers to individual customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be that with dedication and a good pair of scissors, one grocery shopper could get the same coupons — and cheap prices — as another.

articles.headline: Crime Wave Engulfs Syria as Its Cities Reel From War
articles.snippet: Even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away.
articles.abstract: Even in neighborhoods where skirmishes are rare, Syrians say that thieves prey on the weak, and police stations no longer function because the officers have run away.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — The consequences of the war here have become familiar: neighborhoods shelled, civilians killed and refugees departed. But in the background, many Syrians describe something else that has them cowering with fear: a wave of lawlessness not unlike the crime wave Iraq experienced during the conflict there.
articles.byline: By An Employee of The New York Times in Syria and Damien Cave

articles.headline: In Superrich, Clues to What Might Be in Romney’s Returns
articles.snippet: Based on experts’ analysis of data on the wealthiest taxpayers, Mitt Romney has almost certainly been paying income taxes, but perhaps at a very low rate.
articles.abstract: Based on experts’ analysis of data on the wealthiest taxpayers, Mitt Romney has almost certainly been paying income taxes, but perhaps at a very low rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the face of it, Senator Harry Reid’s explosive but flimsily sourced claim that Mitt Romney paid no income tax seems preposterous. Mr. Romney has denied it, and without his returns no one can say for sure. But for someone who makes millions of dollars a year, would it even be possible?

articles.headline: Drought Forces Reductions in U.S. Crop Forecasts
articles.snippet: The United States slashed its estimate of the annual corn crop by 15.5 percent, to its lowest level since 1995, with the cost of processed food, animal feed and ethanol likely to rise.
articles.abstract: The United States slashed its estimate of the annual corn crop by 15.5 percent, to its lowest level since 1995, with the cost of processed food, animal feed and ethanol likely to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the nation’s worst drought in a half-century continuing to decimate crops, the government on Friday slashed its estimate of the soybean yield, made only a month ago, to the lowest level since 2003 and its estimate of the corn yield to the lowest level since 1995.
articles.byline: By Ron Nixon and Annie Lowrey
